results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 23]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film shows the Australian ‘outback’, focussing on Alice Springs. The start of the reel has shots of roads, erosion alongside the roads, surrounding countryside and distant views as well as Kenneth’s car on the road - an image he often used to indicate the film will capture a roadtrip.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:00:00 starts with a title card ‘Hello Alice’.

00:31:00:00 Map of Australia honing in on Alice Springs.

00:46:00:00 sign ‘Pichi Richi Pass - Caution - Creeks and Corners’.

00:1:09:0000:01:47:00 we sight a small steam train.

00:02:10:00 a rail bridge.

00:02:38:00 travellers arrive at the township of Quorn (South Australia)

00:03:01:00 the Quorn train station; long transport steam trains. sign for the township of Marree.

00:04:15:00 footage includes looking at the wheels and tracks, passengers awaiting trains, local Indigenous people, scenes of the outback taken from the train.

00:06:10:00 the traintrip reaches the township of Beresford and then the William Creek Hotel at 00:06:40:00 where we see passengers having fetched bottles of beer from the hotel sprinting back to the train.

00:06:50:00 a glimpse of (probably) brumbies and more scenes of locals and the surrounding countryside from travelling train.

00:09:27:00 we sight traindrivers or workers walking alongside the train, travel by a sheep station and through a very arid landscape.

00:10:20:00 the sign for Alice Springs comes into view. Kenneth starts a tour of the town with some police officers speaking to the camera and footage of families and their cars in one of the streets. Footage includes wandering around the wide dusty roads, people walking and on bicycles and then a look at the buildings - houses, a focus on an older building made (unusually of brick), eucalyptus trees and a flowering garden,

00:11:33:00 we see a sign for the ‘Australian Inland Mission Hostel for bush mothers and children’ on a building that Kenneth gives us several views of including a motorbike outside. This is followed by a view of a new and very modern looking building, surrounded by vegetable or market gardens and out front of which Mrs Rankine chats with acquaintances who point her up to a monument on a hill.

00:12:10:00 is a view from the monument, overlooking the town including views of its oval and what appears to be a prison.

00:13:19:00 view of eucalypts in the surrounding landscape.

00:13:40:00 we see a marker for ‘Flynn’s Grave’ which is a beautiful boulder perched on a stone pedestal.

00:14:04:00 a sign for ‘Standley Chasm’ appears and begins a sequence of dramatic and beautiful scenes of rocky outcrops, foliage and trees. Kenneth films some walkers among the rocks which shows the size and context of the environment.

00:15:31:00 we see two Indigenous horsemen followed by a sign for ‘Hermannsberg’ and some shots of the mission church building, some members of the community and a group of children smiling for the camera. The reel ends with some last looks at the landscape.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 19]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film shows views across the Melbourne CBD rooftops and steeples, a selection of ‘flowering gums’, a visit to the Botanical Gardens, the arrival of ‘flat tops’ aircraft carrier ships. Kenneth then shows off the neon signs of Melbourne at night.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:20:00 title ‘Melbourne’.

00:00:26:00 views from what appears to be the top of the Royal Melbourne Children’s Hospital in North Melbourne with a note, ‘From Here 178 Feet’ beginning with a view down Elizabeth St toward the CBD.

00:01:06:00 an eastern view, where the Dandenong Ranges can be seen in the distance.

00:01:28:00 to 00:01:37:00 views over Melbourne University toward Queen’s College and the Royal Exhibition Building.

00:01:58:00 a horse and cart enter a city intersection at same time as a tram and cars.

00:02:47:00 Melbourne Technical College rotunda.

00:03:05:00 the Pelaco sign in Richmond (a Heritage Victoria listed landmark). Pelaco is a Melbourne based shirt manufacturing business.

00:30:00:00 Elizabeth St with Flinders St Station in view ends the footage of the rooftops of Melbourne.

00:04:30:00 title card ‘Flowering Gums’ followed by a selection of trees and shrubs in flower.

00:06:52:00 title card ‘Botanical Gardens’ begins a look at people enjoying the gardens. Footage includes examples of fox furs being worn by some women strolling in the gardens.

00:09:28:00 a quick look at what appears to be Captain Cook’s cottage.

00:09:35:00 title card ‘V.A.C.S On Location’ begins a sequence of what appears to be a film being made.

00:10:45:00 title card ‘The Flat Tops Arrive’ footage of large ships (aircraft carriers) and tugboats in the bay viewed by watchers on a small pier near, presumably, Port Melbourne.

00:12:42:00 a plane goes overhead. The sequence ends at at night on the beach. with people overlooking the bay toward the horizon.

00:15:11:00 title ‘Bright Lights’, a sequence at night showing neon signs around Melbourne.

00:16:03:00 the face of Luna Park in St Kilda.

00:16:24:00 Fostor’s Lager advertising sign.

00:16:35:00 Berger Paints (British Paints) advertising sign.

00:16:40:00 to 00:16:55:00 Swallows and Ariells ‘Follow the Swallow’ sequenced advertisement for Uneeda Biscuits, Plum Pudding and Biscuits Cakes Ice cream.

00:16:58:00 Sunshine Milk advertising sign.

00:17:15:00 Ball and Welch department store sign on Flinders St with the T&G Building sign in the background.

00:17:23:00 shows a longer sequence advertisement for Sennets ice cream featuring a bear eating an ice cream.

00:18:00:00 possibly the top dome of the Royal Exhibition Building lit up.

00:18:25:00 ‘Visit the Zoo’ advertising flashes up on screen.

00:19:05:00 advertisement ‘Mascot Underwear for Men and Boys’ featuring a ram and lamb on his back.

00:19:09:00 ‘Dunlop Tyres’ advertising sign.

00:19:33:00 footage ends with blurred city lights and traffic lights turning to red.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 18]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film records some of the scenes and events during the visit of Queen Elizabeth II and her consort to Victoria in 1954.

Unusually for this Collection, this reel does not open with Kenneth Rankine’s signature title card (as seen in other reels) but instead uses an ‘iris in’ camera effect (where the image opens in a circle, surrounded by black, and then expands to fill the frame). The scene that then appears is of crowds lining streets as a motorcade drives past, followed by further footage of the crowds and mounted police in procession.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:37:00 a banner reading ‘Welcome to Moorabbin’ can be seen, erected at the side of a park, with the flags of Australia and the United Kingdom (the ‘Union Jack’) displayed nearby, as the motorcade passes through the shot. 00:00:41:00 a green tram passes very close to the motorcade. 00:00:59:00 another clearly visible banner reads ‘Welcome to our Royal Visitors’.

00:01:03:00 the scene switches abruptly to footage of an aeroplane in the sky. 00:01:14:00 the camera is back at street-level, as uniformed military personnel march down a tree-lined roadway. 1950s cars and clothing styles are on display in these shots. One interesting feature of the gathering is that quite a few people have brought ladders with them (to allow them to get a view of events over the heads of others in the crowd).

00:04:04:00 we see the tower of Government House flying the Royal Standard flag (this is only flown when a reigning monarch is in residence). 00:04:09:00 More crowd scenes, with Government House visible in the background. 00:04:11:00 An ‘iris out’ effect closes the sequence (the reverse of the ‘iris in effect that opened the reel).

00:04:14:00 the Josef Hochgurtel fountain (outside the Royal Exhibition Building, Melbourne) is seen illuminated at night. This is followed by more footage of night-time, and illuminated signs and decorations (installed in Melbourne’s CBD for the 1954 royal visit). 00:05:01:00 An illuminated cinema sign is advertising screenings of ‘The Robe’, ‘In Cinemascope’ (the film was made in 1953).
00:05:12:00 another ‘iris in’ effect opens the next sequence, which again shows crowds lining the roads leading to Government House, mounted police and motorcade. 00:05:55:00 The Queen’s car passes, with the Queen and Duke just visible in the back seat, and the camera tracking the car’s motion.

00:06:51:00 the scene shifts back to the crowds lining streets, with the Queen’s car again being slowly followed by the camera as it moves along the roadway. 00:07:35:00 another ‘iris out’ effect - with the tower of Government House in the centre of the frame – closes the sequence.

00:07:40:00 the city of Melbourne at night, with illuminated signs and decorations around the city. 00:07:48:00 Flinders Street Station illuminated (seen from Elizabeth Street) with an illuminated ‘Angus & Robertson Booksellers’ sign also visible. 00:07:56:00 illuminated “Foys” sign. 00:08:11:00 illuminated ‘Lyceum’ sign (indicating the Lyceum Theatre, Bourke Street, now demolished). 00:08:24:00 the illuminated dome of Flinders Street Station.

00:09:39:00 central Melbourne, with St Paul’s Cathedral visible on the left and the old Princes Bridge railway station also visible as an old green bus passes through the shot. results.title_for_label: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 18]
results.description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film records some of the scenes and events during the visit of Queen Elizabeth II and her consort to Victoria in 1954.

Unusually for this Collection, this reel does not open with Kenneth Rankine’s signature title card (as seen in other reels) but instead uses an ‘iris in’ camera effect (where the image opens in a circle, surrounded by black, and then expands to fill the frame). The scene that then appears is of crowds lining streets as a motorcade drives past, followed by further footage of the crowds and mounted police in procession.

00:01:03:00 the scene switches abruptly to footage of an aeroplane in the sky. 00:01:14:00 the camera is back at street-level, as uniformed military personnel march down a tree-lined roadway. 1950s cars and clothing styles are on display in these shots. One interesting feature of the gathering is that quite a few people have brought ladders with them (to allow them to get a view of events over the heads of others in the crowd).

results.title: [London, 1963 - 1964]
results.brief_description:
This silent, black-and-white footage of some of the major landmarks of London was shot in 1963–1964 by Australian photographer Robert Lennox Suggett.

Opens with the Royal Marines Band playing, filmed as they march past the Duke of York Column and Waterloo Steps.

00:00:46:00 then Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, Alec Douglas-Home, farewelling a visitor on the steps of Number 10 Downing Street (the headquarters of British government).

00:01:11:00 camera pans down Nelson’s Column (a monument in Trafalgar Square, central London, commemorating Admiral Horatio Nelson.) We then see scenes of Trafalgar Square, with the National Gallery building and fountain both visible.

00:01:22:00 camera lingers on the equestrian statue of King Charles I, with the church of St Martin-in-the-Fields in the background.

00:01:28:00 London traffic, with the camera focussing especially on cabs (taxis).

00:01:43:00 the Admiralty Arch.

00:01:49:00 double-decker London bus in front of some classic 1960’s style adverstising signs in Piccadilly Circus, with the Eros statue visible.

00:02:04:00 Eros statue in close-up.

00:02:22:00 Underground (railway) sign in close-up, followed by scenes in the Underground itself; ticket queues, escalators, and a train coming into a platform.

00:02:46:00 “Piccadilly Circus” station sign visible on the wall of the train tunnel

The film ends with footage of the tunnel, shot from the moving train.

group_siblings.title: [Construction of the Water Tower at Fletcher Jones Factory, Warrnambool, 1967]

production_dates.notes: Creation date recorded on donated film can.

results.title: [Construction of the Water Tower at Fletcher Jones Factory, Warrnambool, 1967]
results.brief_description:
The Fletcher Jones factory and Gardens at 61–81 Flaxman Street, Warrnambool (established 1948) are famous local landmarks and symbolic of the radical approach to industrial relations and the provision of workplace amenities taken by the famous Australian company. The complex, including the Water Tower, was listed on the Victorian Heritage Register in 2006 in recognition of its historic and social significance which notes “…the unusual and successful integration of surplus military structures, buildings and modernist facade in a factory setting. They reflect the resourcefulness and dynamism of Fletcher Jones in the use of war surplus structures and objects during a time of building material shortages.”

The forty-metre-high water tower – built for fire protection and as a booster system – was designed and supervised by Ralph Jones Construction Engineering Services between 1965–1967. [Source: University of Melbourne Archives: Ralph Jones Water Tower Submission and Business Papers].

This silent, black-and-white footage of the tower’s construction was photographed by Australian photographer Robert Lennox Suggett. It is a unique historic documentary record of the construction of an iconic feature of Warrnambool’s – and Victoria’s – industrial heritage.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 28]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film titled ‘Fragments of 1940’, contains several segments each with its own title and other smaller scenes. Kenneth’s views around the city and the Botanical Gardens as well as his own garden which often features in his films. We see good examples of signs of the era for shops and businesses such as a large wall sign for ‘Sidney Cooke’ printers: a business which later became CMI Fasteners Manufacturers of NZ. The ‘Our Garden’ segment shows the Rankine home garden where Kenneth captures the family circle enjoying themselves among the flowers, trees and gardening activities. There is a look at an Anzac Day parade and friends appear in military uniform - a reminder of the current war. There is also a segment showing daughter Bettye’s school sports day (uniforms indicate possible colleges, Genazzano and Vaucluse).

Selected highlights list:
00:00:11:00 title card ‘Fragments of 1940’ followed by sub-title, ‘Melbourne’ begins the footage with panoramic views around Melbourne, possibly taken from somewhere in Elizabeth St as smoke from industry can be seen on the horizon presumably to the west and buildings in Elizabeth feature later in the reel.

00:01:30:00 there is a view likely to be from Royal Parade looking down Elizabeth St including the Queen Victoria Market to the right of the screen at 00:00:00:00. Scenes following feature some examples of the trams and cars of the 1940’s era.

00:01:55:00 there is a dockside shot likely to be Port Melbourne. Footage shows Melbourne buildings in the CBD including the roof of the APA Tower in Collins St.

00:02:19:00 we see examples of Melbourne’s business signs of the time on various buildings including half a very recognisable Myer store sign as well as Flinders St Station facade at the end of the street.

00:02:37:00 title card ‘Botanical Gardens Melbourne’ appears beginning a segment of views around the Gardens.

00:03:35:00 the conservatory at the Botanical Gardens.

00:06:31:00 school girls participating in athletic sports in a park.

00:08:24:00 cricket teams take over the park while the school gives out the prizes for the day.

00:10:06:00 starts scenes at several beaches with members of the Rankine family and possibly friends. We see swimmers as well as beach strolling and the Rankines under a large umberella.

00:12:33:00 the Rankines return to a garden setting and house verandah, possibly situated in the Dandenongs.

00:13:09:00 title ‘Our Garden’ appears followed by sub-title ‘Come into our Garden’ which is filmed on glass looking through to a colourful garden and one of the Rankine family beckoning us in.

00:13:47:00 scenes of the women in the Rankine circle potting flowers.

00:14:50:00 ball games in the garden driveway.

00:15:11:00 an interesting shot of two of the Rankine women walking along the driveway, seemingly one to work (books and briefcase) and daughter Bettye to school (books in hand). Followed by shots of trees and flowers.

00:16:10:00 Mrs Rankine hosing the garden and Bettye prepared for tennis. More shots of shrubs and flowers.

00:17:17:00 Kenneth shows us a family member or friend in what appears to be her military uniform. Followed by Mrs Rankine cutting flowers.

00:17:40:00 members of the Rankine circle posing for the camera in the garden and the front steps of the house, showing its name, ‘Dunmore’. These shots include a wider circle than usual in Kenneth’s films and also show us a variety of the style of clothes of the day.

00:18:19:00 and indoor shot ends the reel where we see Bettye sitting and chatting to a friend in his military uniform.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is more whimsical in approach than the family based footage seen in other films, as reflected by the title ‘Open Road Open Sky’. In the opening scene we see Kenneth a fellow traveller wandering along country roads as well as shots of roads into the distance and the skies overhead. Further into the reel we see the Sherbrooke Forest, the ‘Burnham Beeches’ and ‘Alfred Nicholson Memorial Gardens’. There are shots of several animals such as emu and echidna as well as quite a bit of birdlife and Kenneth’s favourite shots of flowers and trees. The reel ends with Kenneth walking away from the forests and an end title shot.

Selected sequence list:

00:00:27:00 title ‘Open Road Open Sky’, Kenneth and a fellow traveller wandering along country roads.

00:01:00:00 large power poles along country roads, a few examples of country houses.

00:01:47:00 kangaroos and peacocks.

00:02:45:00 Kenneth walks along a road with his camera.

00:03:14:00 an emu, echidna and a wallaby come into view.

00:04:15:00 close up of Kenneth filming behind his camera followed by ‘Burnham Beeches’ mansion and estate in Sherbrooke Forest and the ‘Alfred Nicholson Memorial Gardens’.

00:06:31:00 birdlife inlcuding storks and lyrebirds.

00:07:44:00 Indigenous rider on horseback, waving at the camera whilst he rounds up horses, camels and Shetland ponies on grassland.

00:08:07:00 brolgas (filmed only from neck down only so difficult to be certain).

00:10:03:00 a quick shot of a woman behind the camera.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 15]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is comprised of two parts. Firstly, travelling on a road tour through South Gippsland from Wilson’s Promontory to Walhalla, Kenneth shows his appreciation of the Australian countryside as he shows the landscape, forests, shorelines and features around him. At times. Kenneth himself appears in the reel on the other side of camera. When at Wilson’s Promontary the footage indicates the style of camping at the time: individual cabins alongside shared facilities likely to have included bathrooms, kitchen and laundry and recreation rooms. Kenneth also shows the old goldtown of Walhalla with its deserted atmosphere. The last part of the reel shows a waterski regatta and speed boats on Albert Park Lake in Melbourne.

Selected highlights list:

(No title)
00:00:00:00 to 00:00:27:00 distant views and roads on the way though what we will come to know is Gippsland.

00:00:32:00 ‘Wilson’s Promontory’ sign, posted alongside the Darby Bridge, its sign and Bob Wootton standing on the bridge.

00:00:38:00 Kenneth Rankine himself looking out over the Darby River.

00:00:45:00 to 00:01:40:00 views of the sea over low lying hills followed by shots of teatree, country roads leading down to the sea, views of the coastline, rocky hills and flower shots.

00:01:42:00 ‘Tidal River’ camping grounds. Just before departing the Prom, there is a lovely view of what appears to be Norman Bay near Tidal River.

00:02:04:00 a sign for ‘Port Welshpool’ followed by views of an estuary at low tide, several piers and fishing boats.

00:02:36:00 a fisherman appears (as indicated by thigh high galoshes) walking along a pier and chatting to Bob Wootton.

00:03:01:00 a sign for the ‘Balook Private Hotel Excellent Accommodation’.

00:03:28:00 after more hillsides and views we see a sign for ‘Bulga Park Shire of Alberton’ (which existed 1855 to 1994; currently Shire of Wellington).

00:04:28:00 sign for Tarra Valley Park appears. In this footage Kenneth has gone to some trouble to capture the Parks, framing his shots of waterfalls, ferns and trees through bracken fronds, branches or rope walks to create a lush feel.

00:06:32 the Corrigan Suspension (walk) Bridge. Shortly after, we are looking down on the Thomson River. Kenneth includes several shots of bridges including the first from which he takes footage of the river below.

00:07:02:00 perhaps foot bridge evident by the scratched initials on the railing. Rail and road bridges are shot from different angles from 00:06:48 to 00:07:02:00.

00:07:10:00 Walhalla Post Office; some deserted and derelict buildings, a shop sign for ‘Agent of the State Savings Bank Guaranteed by the Government of Victoria’ on the door of a derelict Teashop, the Walhalla Station sign on a building which houses old carts with a shot of ‘1903’ on one of the carts, elaborate stone walls.

00:08:11:00 a working timber mill. There are more shots of overgrown brick remnants of buildings in the steep hillsides, rail tracks and old cars.

00:08:41:00 Bob Wootton works a rail lever to move the old tracks. Kenneth has taken views of the town that reflect the almost abandoned state of Walhalla at the time, following the end of the gold mining boom and after the ‘Black Friday’ bushfires that ravaged the State in 1939.

00:08:54:00 program for the ‘A Speedboat and Water - Ski Regatta assisted by the Sirocco Cherokee and Yarrawonga Water Ski Clubs’, held at Albert Park Lake (Melbourne) in 1956. Footage of speedboat racing on the lake follows.

00:10:21:00 a helicopter is filmed flying and hovering overhead.

00:10:30:00 men water skiing; good examples of male swimming trunks. A largish crowd of onlookers and several lakeside buildings.

00:11:37:00 ski jumps.

00:12:40:00 footage of an early display of kitesurfing.

00:07:02:00 perhaps foot bridge evident by the scratched initials on the railing. Rail and road bridges are shot from different angles from 00:06:48 to 00:07:02:00.

00:07:10:00 Walhalla Post Office; some deserted and derelict buildings, a shop sign for ‘Agent of the State Savings Bank Guaranteed by the Government of Victoria’ on the door of a derelict Teashop, the Walhalla Station sign on a building which houses old carts with a shot of ‘1903’ on one of the carts, elaborate stone walls.

00:08:11:00 a working timber mill. There are more shots of overgrown brick remnants of buildings in the steep hillsides, rail tracks and old cars.

00:08:41:00 Bob Wootton works a rail lever to move the old tracks. Kenneth has taken views of the town that reflect the almost abandoned state of Walhalla at the time, following the end of the gold mining boom and after the ‘Black Friday’ bushfires that ravaged the State in 1939.

00:08:54:00 program for the ‘A Speedboat and Water - Ski Regatta assisted by the Sirocco Cherokee and Yarrawonga Water Ski Clubs’, held at Albert Park Lake (Melbourne) in 1956. Footage of speedboat racing on the lake follows.

00:10:21:00 a helicopter is filmed flying and hovering overhead.

00:10:30:00 men water skiing; good examples of male swimming trunks. A largish crowd of onlookers and several lakeside buildings.

00:11:37:00 ski jumps.

00:12:40:00 footage of an early display of kitesurfing.
description_for_label:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is comprised of two parts. Firstly, travelling on a road tour through South Gippsland from Wilson’s Promontory to Walhalla, Kenneth shows his appreciation of the Australian countryside as he shows the landscape, forests, shorelines and features around him. At times. Kenneth himself appears in the reel on the other side of camera. When at Wilson’s Promontary the footage indicates the style of camping at the time: individual cabins alongside shared facilities likely to have included bathrooms, kitchen and laundry and recreation rooms. Kenneth also shows the old goldtown of Walhalla with its deserted atmosphere. The last part of the reel shows a waterski regatta and speed boats on Albert Park Lake in Melbourne.

Selected highlights list:

(No title)

00:00:38:00 Kenneth Rankine himself looking out over the Darby River.

00:00:45:00 to 00:01:40:00 views of the sea over low lying hills followed by shots of teatree, country roads leading down to the sea, views of the coastline, rocky hills and flower shots.

00:01:42:00 ‘Tidal River’ camping grounds. Just before departing the Prom, there is a lovely view of what appears to be Norman Bay near Tidal River.

00:02:04:00 a sign for ‘Port Welshpool’ followed by views of an estuary at low tide, several piers and fishing boats.

00:02:36:00 a fisherman appears (as indicated by thigh high galoshes) walking along a pier and chatting to Bob Wootton.

00:03:01:00 a sign for the ‘Balook Private Hotel Excellent Accommodation’.

00:03:28:00 after more hillsides and views we see a sign for ‘Bulga Park Shire of Alberton’ (which existed 1855 to 1994; currently Shire of Wellington).

00:04:28:00 sign for Tarra Valley Park appears. In this footage Kenneth has gone to some trouble to capture the Parks, framing his shots of waterfalls, ferns and trees through bracken fronds, branches or rope walks to create a lush feel.

00:06:32 the Corrigan Suspension (walk) Bridge. Shortly after, we are looking down on the Thomson River. Kenneth includes several shots of bridges including the first from which he takes footage of the river below.

00:07:02:00 perhaps foot bridge evident by the scratched initials on the railing. Rail and road bridges are shot from different angles from 00:06:48 to 00:07:02:00.

00:07:10:00 Walhalla Post Office; some deserted and derelict buildings, a shop sign for ‘Agent of the State Savings Bank Guaranteed by the Government of Victoria’ on the door of a derelict Teashop, the Walhalla Station sign on a building which houses old carts with a shot of ‘1903’ on one of the carts, elaborate stone walls.

00:08:11:00 a working timber mill. There are more shots of overgrown brick remnants of buildings in the steep hillsides, rail tracks and old cars.

00:08:41:00 Bob Wootton works a rail lever to move the old tracks. Kenneth has taken views of the town that reflect the almost abandoned state of Walhalla at the time, following the end of the gold mining boom and after the ‘Black Friday’ bushfires that ravaged the State in 1939.

00:08:54:00 program for the ‘A Speedboat and Water - Ski Regatta assisted by the Sirocco Cherokee and Yarrawonga Water Ski Clubs’, held at Albert Park Lake (Melbourne) in 1956. Footage of speedboat racing on the lake follows.

00:10:21:00 a helicopter is filmed flying and hovering overhead.

00:10:30:00 men water skiing; good examples of male swimming trunks. A largish crowd of onlookers and several lakeside buildings.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 24]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 24 contains footage of the royal visit to Flemington, also seen in Reels 1, 9, and 10 of this Collection.

Detailed Description Reel 24:

Reel 24 contains footage of the royal visit to Flemington (also seen in Reels 1, 9, and 10 of this Collection). It opens with footage of the Queen and Duke arriving, followed by aerial shots of the horses, jockeys and course. 00:03:25:00 the Queen presenting the winners’ trophy begins. 00:05:50:00 footage of horses racing. 00:07:40:00 to 00:08:33:00 the footage action is in reverse (including Queen and official party, horses and jockeys in mounting yard and racing, and crowd scenes.)

results.brief_description:

Reel 23 contains footage of the children’s display at the Melbourne Cricket Ground (also seen in Reel 8).

Detailed Description Reel 23:

The whole Reel is devoted to footage of the children’s display at the Melbourne Cricket Ground (also seen in Reel 8, B2003230). 00:02:32:00 the Queen and Duke are seen getting out of car and walking across the grass, before the camera returns to the athletics, dancing, marching and costumes of the assembled children. There are also scenes of the children relaxing and playing games when not ‘performing’ on the MCG.
